abstract.p: Continuous viscosity of the sugar melt ranged from the superheated to the supercooled, was measured with a rotating viscometer. The thermal properties of sugars have been investigated by differential scanning calorimetric and thermogravimetry. The melt fragility and the fragility of the supercooled liquid have been calculated. This study indicated that, for the whole sugar system, the melt fragility and the fragility of the supercooled liquid separately show negative linear relations with the glass-forming ability and can be used as indicators of this property. In an individual sugar system, the fragility of the supercooled liquid has a direct proportion to melt fragility, which depends on the different inherent characteristic temperatures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Sugars are important carbohydrates, with a wide distribution in nature. Most foods contain sugars, which can be digested and absorbed to provide energy. Sugars also have wide application as natural preservatives (Slade and Levine, 1991; Hinrichs et al., 2001; Mazzobre et al., 2001) and food additives (Oakes, 2005) in our daily life. They play major roles in influencing glass transition temperature (Tg) in food systems (Jouppila and Ross, 1994; Ahmed et al., 2007). Their glass forming ability (GFA) and Tg have significant effects on the food texture and food stability as well as food conservation in related literatures (Roos et al., 1996; Hartel, 2001; Ahmed et al., 2007).

In addition, glassy sugar can protect cell tissue and stabilize proteins from inactivation or denaturation caused by kinds of stress conditions (Hinrichs et al., 2001; Cummins et al., 2006; Grigera and Bolzicco, 2008). Cicerone and Soles (Cicerone and Soles, 2004; Cummins et al., 2006) noted that preservation of biological agents in nominally dry carbohydrate glasses has become increasingly important in the pharmaceutical and tissue engineering industries which rely on the ability to deliver functional proteins in the dry state.

Researching glass transition of the sugars and producing sugar products with a good GFA and stability, which can be widely used in confectionery dehydrated, concentrated dairy products as well as pharmaceutical excipients (Cicerone and Soles, 2004), becomes one of the active research areas and have attracted lots of attentions over the world (Cicerone and Soles, 2004; Cummins et al., 2006).

Viscosity of the melt is considered as an important parameter to describe the process of kinetic slowdown when the melt is supercooled (Sastry, 2001; Novikov and Sokolov, 2004; Song et al., 2009). It is an important property both for making amorphous materials and for deep insight into the structure of the melts (Meng et al., 2006; Wu et al., 2007). Furthermore, it has a close relation with the GFA of materials.

Angell et al. (Angell, 1985; Böhmer and Angell, 1992; Böhmer et al., 1993) proposed the fragility of supercooled liquid (m) to represent the deviation of the temperature dependent of viscosity from Arrhenius equation in the glass transition region. It is commonly used to classify the strong-fragile characteristics of glass-forming liquids which merely focuses on the glass transition region and has a serious limitation, not to be used to predict the GFA when the glass transition ended. Bian et al. (Bian et al., 2005; Sun et al., 2008) have paid more attention to the superheated melts, the initial states for quenching amorphous materials. They attempted to use viscosity variation rate of the superheated melts towards the liquidus temperature, which has been defined as M, to predict the GFA and describe the structural change in the metallic amorphous alloys. Where Tl is the liquidus temperature and η(Tl) is the viscosity at liquidus. Furthermore, M establishes the relationship between viscosity and glass-forming ability. Glass forming ability and its relation with viscosity are also critical for the application of sugar and its water mixture in food industry (Ren et al., 2010).

However, the nature of M and its relation with the intrinsic temperature are not fully understood until now. Besides, the correlation between M, which stands for the beginning of the quenching amorphous materials and m which indicates the end of the quenching glasses process is very fascinating and has not been concerned necessarily.

In this article, we calculated M and m of sugar melts with low molecule weight. Moreover, the correlations among melt fragility, the fragility of supercooled liquids and glass-forming ability were discussed, which may be helpful to understand the glass formation and GFA of sugar melt.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
The samples used in this study were sucrose, D-fructose and D-galactose. The monosaccharide and disaccharide were chosen as their Tg are near the room temperature (when they are dry, as pure amorphous components) and they have good GFA. Sugar chemicals are from Beijing Solarbio Science and Technology Co. and are used without further purification. The thermal properties of the sugars under high temperature were characterized by a Netzsch DSC404 calorimeter using pure indium (99.999 wt%) and pure zinc (99.999 wt%) standards, giving an accuracy of ± 0.3 K for the temperature, ± 18 µV/(mW) for the energy measurements, and a Netzsch TG 209 C with an Argon flow rate of 60 mL/min. The Tg of D-fructose was investigated by a Netzsch DSC204F1 calorimeter with a shielding argon flow rate of 60 mL/min (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Low temperature of DSC curve for D-fructose at a heating rate of 20 K/min (Tg = 299.15 K).

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Viscosity measurements were performed in an air atmosphere with a rotating viscometer (Theta industries, inc. USA). The sample was placed in an alumina crucible supported by three graphite rods. After that, it was heated to at least 5 K above the liquidus temperature at a speed of 5 K/min using oil bath equipment (MeiXiang, Shanghai, China) and held for 15 min and then naturally cooled. Viscosity measurements were performed during cooling processes by graphite rotator. The viscosity was calculated by measuring the rotor torque using the equation: (2)

The critical cooling rate Rc, which is the minimum cooling rate to form glass without crystallization during solidification, is an essential parameter to evaluate the GFA of a melt. The smaller Rc, the higher GFA. However, it is difficult to precisely measure Rc. Therefore, many other criteria, which can be simply calculated on the basis of characteristic temperatures measured by thermal analysis, have been proposed to correlate with GFA (Turnbull, 1969; Inoue et al., 1993; Lu and Liu, 2002). The most extensively used is Trm, the reduced glass transition temperature. (3)

Where Tg is the glass transition temperature and Tm is the melting temperature. Tl, the liquidus temperature, usually replaces Tm for alloys and mixtures. The higher Trm is, the better the glass-forming ability. The characteristic temperatures of these sugar melts are summarized in Table 1. Because of different laboratory facilities, there are slight differences in characteristic temperatures between our work and the values of Kim and Karis (1995). However, the values of Trm are very close and share the same trend of D-galactose > D-fructose >Sucrose. The values of m of sugar melts are shown in Table 2. Obviously, m shows a linear relationship with Trm. The smaller value of m has, the larger value of Trm is. According to the concept of m, the fragility infers that fragile liquids would experience rapid breakdown of structure with decreasing temperature approaching Tg. In contrast, strong liquid has a slow structure change (Angell, 1985; Böhmer et al., 1993). So m can indicate the relative stability of the supercooled liquids and these liquids are more stable and stronger with the decreasing value of m.

Melt fragility directly reflects the viscosity variation with decreasing temperature. Viscosity is a structural sensitive property at an atomic scale. The changes of the liquid structure result in the changes of viscosity. Liquid with a higher M undergoes a more rapid structural rearrangement toward the melting point than that with a lower M. A more stable melt with a smaller M is easier to be frozen into the amorphous phase.

The relationship among m, M and Trm is showed in Figure 6. It is interesting to find nearly linear proportional correlations between M and m. M stands for the beginning state of the quenching amorphous materials and m indicates the ending state of the quenching glasses process. They manifest a linear relation and each has a negative correlation with Trm. Small microstructural change in the parent melt reflected as small M results in the inheritance of the stable structure during solidification, and thus it is easy to be frozen when amorphous phase reflected as a small m. The inherent characteristic temperatures (Tg, Tm) of sugar melts determine the correlation between m and M in an individual sugar system. It explains the behavior of m and M, and the relation among Trm, m and M.

Melt fragility and fragility of supercooled liquids are two different concepts in nature because they reflect the stability and structure characteristic of superheated melts and supercooled liquids, respectively. M is mainly focused on the superheated melts. It uses the glassy characteristic of parent melts and inheritance to describe the GFA of the glassy materials. For the solid amorphous state, m is valuable and directly to reflect the stability and the variation in the structure of glasses.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Viscosity of sugar melts varies with temperature. The values of melt fragility M, and the fragility of the supercooled liquids m, were calculated. The results show that M as a GFA indicator is well satisfied in sugar system. For the whole sugar system, M and m exhibit a good linear relation with Trm, respectively. The more stable the superheated melt is, the stronger the supercooled liquid becomes and the better GFA is. Moreover, the ratio (M/m) exhibits a good proportion correlation with the Trm. It explains the fascinating relation between the melt fragility and the fragility of the supercooled liquids.
